A Harley biker is riding by the zoo in Washington, DC when he sees a little
 girl leaning into the lion's cage. Suddenly, the lion grabs her by the cuff
 of her jacket and tries to pull her inside to slaughter her, under the eyes
 of her screaming parents. 
 
 The biker jumps off his Harley, runs to the cage and hits the lion square on
 the nose with a powerful punch. Whimpering from the pain the lion jumps back
 letting go of the girl, and the biker brings her to her terrified parents,
 who thank him endlessly. 
 
 A reporter has watched the whole event. The reporter addressing the Harley
 rider says, 'Sir, this was the most gallant and brave thing I've seen a man
 do in my whole life.' The Harley rider replies, 'Why, it was nothing,
 really, the lion was behind bars. I just saw this little kid in danger and
 acted as I felt right.' 
 
 The reporter says, 'Well, I'll make sure this won't go unnoticed. I'm a
 journalist, and tomorrow's paper will have this story on the front page...
 So, tell me about yourself.' 
 
 The biker replies, 'I'm a U.S. Marine and a Republican.' 
 The journalist leaves.
 
 The following morning the biker buys the paper to see news of his actions,
 and reads, on the front page: 
 
 ________________________________________
 
 U.S. MARINE ASSAULTS AFRICAN IMMIGRANT AND STEALS HIS LUNCH

post_info.post_title: Here is one for the Hate America first crowd:

Now this is funny!
 
   Allan Driver bailed over seizure of military guns 
 A BANNED gun capable of firing 700 rounds a minute, and another with a range of two kilometres have been bought by undercover NSW police during a year-long sting operation.
 
 "As a result of these investigations, undercover officers were able to purchase a range of illegal firearms, including a Kalashnikov, a .50 calibre sniper rifle and an AK47 rifle," Superintendent Arthur Katsogiannis said this afternoon. 
 
 In raids on two Sydney properties this week, police seized an additional 14 illegal firearms.
 
 "The Kalashnikov, we believe, is the first of its kind ever seen in NSW," Supt Katsogiannis said. ......... 3,600 rounds of 7.62 calibre ammunition

   Police raid Agape Ministries of God doomsday cult properties 
 Supt Jeffery said police were concerned that while ammunition was found in the raids, high-powered guns believed to be possessed by the cult were missing.
 
 Fifteen illegal firearms and extendable batons were found in the raids, while Major Fraud detectives also seized financial records.
 
 
   Two charged with making illegal guns 
 Two men, including a bikie, have been charged over the manufacture of illegal firearms after police allegedly seized rifles, knuckledusters and firearms parts in raids in Sydney.
 
 A 43-year-old man was arrested and police allegedly seized a submachine-gun, several registered and unregistered rifles and other firearm parts.

 
    Former bikie jailed over illegal arsenal 
 A reformed bikie caught with an arsenal of weapons and ammunition stashed in a secret cupboard at his Adelaide home has been jailed for more than six years.
 Police found eight guns and more than 3000 rounds of ammunition, hidden in the wall cavity of the laundry at the suburban North Haven address where William John Davis, 51, lived in 2006.
 His cache of weapons included three assault rifles, bolt action rifles, semi-automatic shotguns and a .38 calibre revolver.

 
   Organised crime is out of control 
…….
 Capturing 300 illegal guns in four years might have struck South Australians as less of a triumph had Rann mentioned that more than 500 weapons, including handguns, were stolen in a single home invasion of a firearms dealer north of Adelaide in 1999.
 As gang violence raged across south-western Sydney early this decade, the Carr government blamed the Commonwealth for the number of illegal guns. "There's no point our police chasing their tails on Sydney streets trying to get handguns off those streets," then police minister Michael Costa said, "if the Federal Government is letting down the side by not dealing with the question of the source, and that is the illegal handguns that come across our porous borders."

 
 Machine Guns? But I thought????????

Nope, this is a myth that's been disproven time and time again. Only a tiny fraction of all the weapons in Mexico have been traced back to the United States.

 
 Mexico's Drug War: "The Myth of 90 Percent: Only a Small Fraction of Guns in Mexico Come From U.S."

Mexico's Drug War: "The Myth of 90 Percent: Only a Small Fraction of Guns in Mexico Come From U.S."

 
 From blog:
 
Because I still work in this business and (a) want to keep my job, (b) want to continue to get good, reliable information, and (c) don't want to get any of my colleagues and contacts in trouble, I can't tell you the names of my sources or the agencies they work for.

 
 No need to read any further.

Mexico's Drug War: "The Myth of 90 Percent: Only a Small Fraction of Guns in Mexico Come From U.S."

 Interesting. As I understand, the author is saying that the argument that only 17% of seized guns came from the US is statistically unsound. Suppose you surveyed 1,000 people in a town that has a population of 100,000 and 90% of those interviewed said that they owned a dog. It would be a mistake to assume that the 99,000 not interviewed did not own dogs and that therefore the dog ownership rate must be less than 1%. The authors of that Fox news article seem to be making the same mistake- automatically assuming that guns not submitted for tracing do not come from the US.

Interesting. As I understand, the author is saying that the argument that only 17% of seized guns came from the US is statistically unsound. Suppose you surveyed 1,000 people in a town that has a population of 100,000 and 90% of those interviewed said that they owned a dog. It would be a mistake to assume that the 99,000 not interviewed did not own dogs and that therefore the dog ownership rate must be less than 1%. The authors of that Fox news article seem to be making the same mistake- automatically assuming that guns not submitted for tracing do not come from the US.

 
 Your comparison fails. Mexico turned over only a minute number of recovered firearms for the ATF to trace. That's far different from performing a survey of the people.
 
 Try again.

I’m really undecided on the issue of guns going into Mexico from the US. I just don’t think there is enough data to reliably inform us how bad the situation is. I don’t necessarily accept the Fox article. Ms Longmire does have some accurate criticism of it. However, I did find a lot of bias and error in her piece, and I want to comment upon it….
 
 I find it interesting that Ms. Longmire starts with the claim that she has it on “good authority” from a “trusted source” that the Fox article is incorrect and misleading. It’s very much a “trust me, I’m on the inside and I know” statement. 
 
 She expects me to accept this on faith, for, as she explains, “I can't tell you the names of my sources or the agencies they work for.” Nor, apparently, can she disclose any of the information she has obtained from these insider sources. You see, I really expected to find some proof of this insider knowledge. All I found in the rest of the article was information that could be gleaned from publically available internet sources. It is odd to me to see her make the claim that she possesses insider knowledge proving the Fox article is wrong—and then offer none of that evidence. She might have well said “I’ve got this secret knowledge, but if I told you then I would have to kill you.” 
 
 And so, since she is unwilling to offer any information from her special contacts, she starts with an upfront admission: “That DOES NOT MEAN THEY DID NOT COME FROM THE US...that just means no one can prove it through checking a database.” (bold emphasis added by me) In other words, there is no evidence to show, and no one can prove, that these untraced weapons came from the US.
 
 However, Ms. Longmire then makes the argument that despite the lack of any proof there is a “pretty good chance” that “somewhere close” to the desired 90% figure is true. What wonderfully vague language! That’s like saying if a grenade lands “somewhere close” then there is a “pretty good chance” you might catch some shrapnel. To base policy decisions on such hopeful analysis is like saying we need not take any more action because BP tell us there is a “pretty good chance” it will capture “somewhere close” to all the oil leaking in the future from the gulf wellhead. 
 
 And how can this assumption that the guns “probably” are of US origin have any merit when the very next sentence reads: “I’m not sure how anyone can tell just by looking at a gun that it definitely was not originally sold in the US.”? For this, you see, exposes the assumed bias built into the argument: I want the percentage of guns from the US to be high, so I will assume, unless proven otherwise, that if you can’t tell by looking at it then there is a “pretty good chance” the gun came from the US. I admit there is no proof that the weapon came from the US, but absent any proof that it didn’t I will assume a “pretty good chance” it came from the US. It is a very poor argument in my opinion, and I doubt whether Ms. Longmire understands how she has exposed her bias. Particularly when she later follows up with this curious comment:
 
 “I'm also not a fan of the implication the authors make that just because a gun doesn't have a serial number (more and more weapons seized in Mexico have the serial numbers filed off), it probably didn't come from the US. Based on the TYPE of weapon seized (such as a semi-automatic handun or revolver or rifle), you CAN REASONABLY ASSUME it was sold - probably legally - in the US and moved south into Mexico.”
 
 Do you see the doublespeak that exists here?: I’ve already agreed no evidence exists to link these untraced guns to the US, and no one can prove they did come from the US. But I don’t like “implications.” I don’t think the Fox article authors should assume that a gun without a serial number didn’t come from the US—because I would rather asume that such firearms did come from the US. The clear “implication” is that in the absence of facts it’s OK to assume so long as the assumption helps my theory. 
 
 Now let me say what I know about tracing. Guns sold in the US will have a serial number. It is a crime to have any firearm in the US without an identifiable serial number (18 U.S.C. § 922): 
 
 It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to transport, ship, or receive, in interstate or foreign commerce, any firearm which has had the importer's or manufacturer's serial number removed, obliterated, or altered or to possess or receive any firearm which has had the importer's or manufacturer's serial number removed, obliterated, or altered and has, at any time, been shipped or transported in interstate or foreign commerce.
 
 All guns sold in the US must start with a serial number. If a gun is recovered with a serial number, then ATF can contact the manufacturer and discover whether the firearm was delivered to an original point of sale in the US market. If the number has been obliterated, then ATF can, if requested, recover the serial number in the vast majority of cases by a process of acid etching. I’ve seen it done by our lab in Virginia. It is really a question of how much time and resources you are willing to devote to finding out the origins of guns with an obliterated serial number. Do we really know what resources the two governments are devoting to finding out how many guns came from the US market? But then again, do we even know how many guns recovered in Mexico have had their serial numbers destroyed? Ms. Longmire says the number is “more and more”? What does that mean? 10? 100? 1,000? She is supposed to have the inside contacts, and she has no idea how many?
 
 So what about Ms. Longmire’s complaint that guns can be built out of spare parts in the US and then be shipped to Mexico? It is possible, but I have a hard time accepting that a large number of guns in Mexico come from a US parts assembly process. She cites a website that claims these parts can be legally shipped into the US. If the parts are sold outside the US and are available for import and remanufacture, then why not just bring the parts directly into Mexico for assembly? Why build them here and go through the trouble of smuggling them across the border? The logic escapes me….
 
 To be fair, she suggests this may be done because the parts assembler either needs or chooses to use a “US-made receiver,” when building a gun out of parts. How many of these assembled parts guns get to Mexico? 50-100-1,000-10,000? Again, her insider sources appear lacking, and she does not even hazard a guess. But whatever the number, she confidently asserts these guns are “probably” untraceable:
 
 "A DTO-obtained assault weapon put together in the US using AK-47 parts and a US-made receiver would probably fall under the "untraceable" category - but it still originated in the US."
 
 Here is that bias again: You can’t prove it, and I don’t have any real idea, but I want to assume these guns “probably” originate in the US. Ms. Longmire makes this assumption while “probably” being unaware of the definition of “firearm” in the US Code (18 U.S.C. § 921):
 
 The term "firearm" means
 
 (A) any weapon (including a starter gun) which will or is designed to or may readily be converted to expel a projectile by the action of an explosive;
 
 (B) the frame or receiver of any such weapon;
 
 (C) any firearm muffler or firearm silencer; or
 
 (D) any destructive device. Such term does not include an antique firearm. (bold emphasis added by me)
 
 And, therefore, the “US-made receiver” would definitely, and not “probably,” contain a traceable serial number. Perhaps some of these guns are assembled from parts and the serial number is then obliterated to make them untraceable. How many? Again, Ms. Longmire has absolutely no idea other than “more and more.” All she knows for certain is that for her it is a “disturbing issue.”
 
 Listen, I don’t dispute that guns go south. The problem, as I see it, is the Mexican drug gangs have such an appetite for killing that the demand for guns has created a vacuum which sucks in firearms from any possible source. But that is the problem. The desire for violence draws the weapons. The availability of the weapons does not manufacture the violence. If that were so, then the violence would be much higher in the US border states where the guns can be had much more easily without any need to smuggle them across an international border. 
 
 The problem with these statistical arguments is they are all guesswork. We simply don’t know the total number of firearms going south. We don’t know how many guns have obliterated serial numbers. We don’t know how many of these ATF has attempted to trace. The Fox analysts don’t know, and neither does Ms. Longmire (despite her claim of possessing the insider federal agency information). What is clear from reading Ms. Longmire’s article is this: Her personal bias finds that the absence of evidence is an invitation to engage in baseless speculation. 
 
 I don’t claim to have all the answers, but I am willing to examine the issue. I just do not believe we should base an attempt to deal with these issues upon the flawed speculation Ms. Longmire offers us.

Clearly bias is introduced into discussions of these statistics by both sides.
 
 We can't say what percentage of the untraceable submitted weapons did in fact originate in the US.
 
 We can't say what percentage of the seized weapons had serial numbers obliterated and therefore weren't submitted but did in fact come from the US.
 
 We can't say what percentage of the seized weapons were intentionally not submitted for whatever reason but did in fact come from the US.
 
 The assumption that all of the unsubmitted weapons did not come from the US is clearly wrong. 
 To assume that the percentage of traced weapons reflects an estimate applicable to the unsubmitted weapons is equally wrong.

The assumption that all of the unsubmitted weapons did not come from the US is clearly wrong. 
 To assume that the percentage of traced weapons reflects an estimate applicable to the unsubmitted weapons is equally wrong.

First of all, your debunking article discovered a math error from 68% to 62%. Wow! First off, we should shoot the author. emoticon_smile
 
 Second, a lot of her analysis is supposition at best. Dose she know how many AK's were supposedly built from parts? Does she know where they got these parts from? Probably not the U.S.. 
 
 One thing I can tell you is that, We ABSOLUTELY Know that any receivers made here in the US are marked! Serial numbered. U.S. AK Parts are marked U.S. too! Why? Because it is illegal for one to have an AK in the U.S. built with too many foreign parts so U.S. AK Parts are clearly marked. Made in the U.S.. 
 
 The ATF boys want it that way, and they are sticklers on that little point too! It is a Federal Offense to boot. So maybe she should have checked into that before she supposed! No? So we can assume that she apparently doesn't know gun laws either, or she may have supposed differently.
 
 By the way, DO YOU know how many of the things you asked of me? You do however, want to suppose that it is the fault of the U.S. gun owners. 
 
 Which means, you want to fly new gun laws on pure supposition, like she did. And Why are we getting blamed for what Criminals do? 
 
 And let me use your source. Sylvia Longmire.
   "Bush aide urges weapons ban to slow Mexican drug war." 
 I don't think the issue of the potential reinstatement of an assault weapons ban can be explained too much. It seems to me that many people are under the impression that DTO enforcers only use assault weapons when they kill people, and that is NOT the case. Yes, they do like some types of assault weapons that they legally buy in the US through straw purchasers, but I'm still convinced that reinstating the ban won't make that much of a dent in the southbound weapons flow problem, or in the levels of violence in Mexico. Here's my analysis from April 2009, in response to an article called "Obama gets gun shy.":
 
 "I'm not a firearms expert, so take my analysis knowing that. However, I was able to do some common sense research, and I came to the conclusion that renewing the assault weapons ban would probably not accomplish much by way of stemming the flow of weapons from the US into Mexico.
 ……
 Another thing that is VERY important to remember is that DTOs are relying more heavily on military-grade weapons, like grenade launchers, hand grenades, and sniper rifles. These types of weapons not only wouldn't fall within an assault weapons ban, but they're not even purchased by DTO reps in the US. Long story short, a weapons ban would likely be yet another ineffective attempt by the Obama Administration to look like it's doing something - anything - to help the Mexico situation.

By the way, DO YOU know how many of the things you asked of me?
Did I not say that we can't speak with any assurance about a number of specifics related to these seized weapons? 
 You mention the military hardware as if that were all that is being seized. Far from it.
 
 
You do however, want to suppose that it is the fault of the U.S. gun owners.
Where do I do that? I suppose that the firearms traced to the US were once part of our legal market. .
